speed.title: Speed
speed.definition: Speed is how fast something is moving, like a cheetah chasing its lunch! It doesn't care about direction, just how quickly it's covering ground.
speed.example: A racing car zipping around a track at 200 km/h is showing its incredible speed.

quiz.question: A turtle crawls 10 meters in 2 minutes. What is its speed?

velocity.title: Velocity
velocity.definition: Velocity is speed with a mission! It's not just how fast you're going, but also *where* you're going. It's a vector, which means it has both speed and direction.
velocity.example: A superhero flying at 800 km/h *towards the north* has a specific velocity.

quiz.question: A car travels east at 40 mph and a bike travels west at 40 mph. Do they have the same velocity?
options: Yes, they have the same speed
Yes, because they are on the same road

acceleration.title: Acceleration
acceleration.definition: Acceleration is any change in velocity. That means speeding up, slowing down, or even just turning a corner! It's the 'vroom vroom' of physics.
acceleration.example: When a rocket blasts off, it's accelerating. When a car hits the brakes, it's also accelerating (just in a negative direction!).

quiz.question: A rollercoaster goes from 0 to 60 mph in 3 seconds. Is it accelerating?
options: Yes, because its speed is changing
quiz.answer: Yes, because its speed is changing

friction.title: Friction
friction.definition: Friction is a force that resists motion when two surfaces rub against each other. It's the universe's way of saying 'slow down!' and it helps us walk and stop.
friction.example: Rubbing your hands together to warm them up creates friction. A car's brakes use friction to stop.

formula_breakdown.description: is the Normal force (how hard they're pressed together).

quiz.question: Which surface would have the MOST friction?

newtons_first_law.title: Newton's First Law
newtons_first_law.definition: An object at rest stays at rest, and an object in motion stays in motion... unless a force messes with it! It's also called the Law of Laziness (Inertia).
newtons_first_law.example: A soccer ball won't move until you kick it. Once kicked, it would keep going forever if friction and air didn't stop it.

formula_breakdown.description: means if all forces are balanced...

quiz.question: Why do you feel pushed forward when a bus suddenly stops?
